body_html:
@soumith Thank you.
@SsnL I was talking about the actual behavior to solve the ambiguity. For your example of 2x2 input, without output_padding the output is 5x5, while with output_padding=1, it should sample one more row (and column) of patches in the input image by extending the size of input by 1, so that the convoluted output size becomes 6x6. It is controlled by the params of im2col in the code referred above.
body_text:
@soumith Thank you.
@SsnL I was talking about the actual behavior to solve the ambiguity. For your example of 2x2 input, without output_padding the output is 5x5, while with output_padding=1, it should sample one more row (and column) of patches in the input image by extending the size of input by 1, so that the convoluted output size becomes 6x6. It is controlled by the params of im2col in the code referred above.
body:
@soumith Thank you.
@SsnL I was talking about the actual behavior to solve the ambiguity. For your example of `2x2 input`, without `output_padding` the output is `5x5`, while with `output_padding=1`, it should sample one more row (and column) of patches in the input image by extending the size of input by 1, so that the convoluted output size becomes `6x6`. It is controlled by the params of im2col in the code referred above.
